review:
I want to give this game a positive recommendation because the idea is great. You move through a world with a handful of weapons, each with key-input combos similar to fighting games, and every fight can end in your death. It was also apparently made by one person. The problem is the game costs real world money and it has too many problems to be fun, and even if it actually achieved its original goal of being a competitive multiplayer or whatever, it still wouldn't work. These are the reasons why I can't recommend it:

It is poorly optimized. I am  running it on a modern laptop that has no trouble playing modern AAA games, but even with everything turned down the game is a laggy mess. The key-input combo system that makes this game unique also makes it a frustrating mess, and it is a very very ugly game to begin with. There are also almost no options to adjust the most intensive things like lighting and physics. You can change the resolution, the draw distance (which even maxed out has pop-in at about 50 feet

It isn't just the lag either. The physics are abysmal. Expect enemies to bug out, disappear, fly away, or be unhittable while  standing right in front of you

The game is also extremely linear and uninteresting. Enemies aren't random and the AI is atrocious to the point where once you compensate for the lag and bugs the game becomes so simple it is a chore. I am several hours in because my OCD demands I try to complete the game since I paid for it, and so far I have fought only one enemy type. There is also no loot. Everyone uses the same weapons as you and when you kill them you can trade your 20 damage sword for their 20 damage sword. A very lazy durability system is the only reason to pick up loot at all

This is also not an RPG. You slowly gain levels, and each level unlocks a new combo for each weapon, of which there are 2 weapon types with 5-6 total moves each, spread over 6 levels. That is it. There are no abilities or stats, no customization or any options for play style. You just walk from fight to fight, heal, rinse, repeat. This makes the leveling system completely pointless.  The combos could have been tied to weapons instead of experience levels, and at least then you would have to beat a tougher opponent to earn new moves

If somehow the game opens up into something more involving it then it take hours of ugly scenery to get there because I haven't seen it yet. I applaud the guy who made it but selling it for $5 in the year where Indie developers gave use Rocket League and Undertale and Megaton Rainfall just isn't right. Minecraft was almost a decade old at this point. So the "1 person" argument doesn't fly. With minimal effort this game could easily have been polished and worth playing,or it could have cost a buck and then there could be a serious conversation of if it was worth being made

review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

review:
KRUM - Edge Of Darkness is a case of what seems to have been a genuine attempt at making a game being grabbed by the unethical asset flippers and shovelware pushers at SA Industry/ZemunBRE/Mikhail Melnikov (they use a lot of shell accounts to try mislead gamers).  SA Industry have a long history of harmful and unethical industry behaviour, so I guess the low quality of this game appealed to them. 

First, of course, about this game.  It's a very badly made third person action adventure game, and while it's sometimes difficult to do, Valve recommends we say something good about games as part of a review.  In this case it seems a huge amount of effort went into map design, level design, plot and quest stuff that was completely wasted on a craptastic technical implementation.  And it really is a waste.. with such bad visuals and gameplay, nobody is going to get into the story. 

HA Studio Ltd./SA Industry have shown a repeat pattern of unethically dumping other people's work onto Steam as a cheap, nasty cash grab, through this account or through closely linked/alt accounts.  Here's some examples so you can see for yourself:
[list]
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1053650]Drive For Your Life[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs/zombie-drive-full-game-template-73074]Zombie Drive - Full Game Template[/url] developed by Puppeteer
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/856490]Falling Words[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs/2d-typing-game-endless-random-falling-word-text-font-typer-game-107867]2D Typing Game[/url] developed by Steelkrill Studio
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/756260]Kingdom Defense[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs/tower-defense-basic-pixel-art-pack-45705]Tower Defense Basic Pixel Art Pack[/url] developed by FreeThePlayerOnGame
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1075790]Fox and Bunny[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/2d/characters/sunny-land-103349]Sunny Land[/url] developed by Ansimuz (as ZemunBRE)
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/827920]Bounce[/url]" = [url=https://nullpress.net/free-download-bounce-mobile-game-unity-project-included/]Bounce Mobile Game Unity Project[/url] developed by GhandiGames (as Mikhail Melnikov)
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/810570]Face[/url]" = [url=https://github.com/BayatGames/RedRunner]Red Runner[/url] developed by Bayat Games (as Mikhail Melnikov)
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/763360]Nice Way[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs/white-peas-61645]White Peas[/url] developed by EVGames (as Mikhail Melnikov)
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/786750]Squares[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs/push-the-squares-69780]Push the Squares Pack[/url] developed by Shorka Games (as Mikhail Melnikov)
[/list]

Despite the producers history of unethical activity and asset flip pollution, I feel this was a genuine attempt to make a game, but it doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.  Possibly why SA Industry were so quick to try get their hands on it for a quick buck. 

The game features lazy low-polygon "retro" assets, making this look like a barely functional 3D game from the 1990s.  It's unclear why the developers weren't able to arrange high quality, high polygon count contemporary assets for the game, and also irrelevant... what matters is that this looks bad as a result of their decisions, a compromise PC gamers shouldn't have to put up with.

The controls and game handling are notably very clunky and unsmooth here.  It's janky and unsatisfying to play... and any experienced gamer will tell you, the handling, responsiveness and general gameplay feel of the control scheme must be well polished for this kind of game to succeed.  Unfortunately, this is something the developer seems to have phoned in, with little to no apparent gameplay testing.  They dropped the ball on this one.

Some of the defects in the game can be attributed to the choice of using an incredible one-two whammy, of Blender Game Engine and PyGame... some of the worst tools in the industry.  This is like throwing a party and hiring Insane Clown Posse to cover Nickelback songs for you.  Blender Game Engine was so bad, Blender abandoned it two years after this game was released (leading us to wonder if this was the straw that broke the camels back).  Just as you can't make a silk purse out of a sows ear, you can't make a great video game if you use a terrible engine.

These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

Reviewing SteamDB to check how popular this game was with players reveals a surprise... there's a very healthy spike in player counts for the game.  But this only appears around the same time that trading cards were applied to the game... so this is just card idlers getting their cards and moving on.  A closer look at the numbers shows the game just has a couple of players every week running up the game and idling it for cards, then deleting it.  We must ask how it benefits gamers for there to be so many games like this, with no merit as a serious game, that only generate sales from people idling and selling the trading cards.

It's also important to note the "developer" here has connections to a number of shady Russian asset flippers and review manipulators who show an organised pattern to scam and defraud gamers with fake reviews and asset flipping the work of others for profit.  While reviews are about the games, gamers should be informed when developers act unethically.   Whether these connections are the same developer using multiple accounts, or just working closely with other unethical developers, gamers should be warned about the harm to gamers by this developer and their associates.  Buying games from unethical developers puts your money at risk.

KRUM - Edge Of Darkness is relatively cheap at $2 USD, but it's not worth it. Given the defects and quality issues with the game, coupled with the unrealistic price, and the questionable ethical nature of the developer and/or their associates (as outlined above), this is impossible to recommend.

review:
This is a big NO recommendation! First, before I even started the game, I had to go to the forum to learn that it's necessary to run the game as admin or it will continue crashing before the main menu. Not a good start. And apparently running the game directly instead of through the launcher does not record playtime, so to get my 5 minutes required to post this review (although I actually "played" it for 15 minutes), I had to start the game, and let it crash, 15 times until Steam recorded 5 minutes.

When I actually got into the game, I saw one of the worst character models in a modern game. It's late '90s modeling in a 2015 game. Just awful. Then I found out I cannot bash crates or barrels without a weapon (which I don't have). Seriously, I cannot kick or punch like every other game ever made? 

I found the dwarf (I think) dude who gave me my first quest, to find my father's sword. The quest-giver was also very poorly animated and looked like he had both legs amputated at the knees. I'd love to post a screenshot, but F12 does not take screenshots in this game, for some reason; it changes the brightness between 2 settings. And you will definitely want to hit F12 to prevent yourself from going blind. The original setting is like looking into the sun.

I then wandered off to find Dad's sword. Went into a house, where I completely disappeared. The game decided to switch from third to first person, but when I tried to pick up objects, I could see my semi-transparent left arm. Getting pretty annoyed, I go outside, where I get stuck in a hay bale. Seriously. I was completely trapped and no amount of jumping, leaping, or attempted running got me out. I did get to hear my character be a complete ass and scold me about how I cannot go each way I tried to go. 

Sorry devs. You may have the beginnings of a decent game here, but as it is, it's just terrible. Completely unplayable. Steam says to me, "None of your friends have played this game recently. Tell them why they should." Unfortunately I have no argument for why my friends should play this.

Does HA Studio stand for "HA! I can't believe people actually bought this junk!"?

review:
Okay, this game? It's bad. I mean, it's really bad.

The plot is the "always memorable" my village and family were attacked and now I have to avenge them kind of thing. Nothing spectacular here. The main character has the personality of a brick, and apparently three voices! Yeah, get this: on story cutscenes he'll sound like this tryhard British nobleman, with horrible voice acting that doesn't even match what the subtitles are showing. His second and third voices? Oh man.

He'll say the same canned 5 lines EVERY TIME he spots an object you can interact with, so get ready to hear "what this is, an object"; or the classic "haha, I'm going to get fat". I say he has two voices ingame because some of these definitely sound like Text to Speech, but when you're not moving, the third voice will come in and start singing...? 

You'll traverse through 8 different levels, although if I were you I'd stop at the end of level 1. Level 1 allows you to hear this "amazing" voice acting by yourself, have a few laughs, and be in awe of how bad and glitchy this game is. It's like watching a bad movie with your friends, it has a few "so bad it's good" moments, high comedic value.

The gameplay..? Umm.. It's a spamfest. Yeah there's a skill list but I never paid attention to it, since most mobs just die by spamming the attack button. Even if they defend they'll eventually try to attack you but since you're already spamming you'll almost always attack first. The framerate gets godawful at times, and for this game, there's no reason. It looks like something out of PS2 games, and I have nothing against dated graphics, only poor optimization. I love how the game has ranged weapons, and you can use these, yet there is no normal enemy that thinks of even using a bow. Dark Souls this ain't.

There's this Survival Mode with leaderboards but the bad gameplay doesn't justify its presence whatsoever.

It also started putting in jumping puzzles in a certain level as if the engine itself is good for such things. 

The soundtrack...? I remember it had tracks that looped for the entire level, and these can take a while. There's only one combat theme but I wasn't expecting variation there. No track comes to mind. Forgettable at best, annoying at worst.

I am fully aware this was a one man team development for this game and while that is admirable, doing such a sloppy job and making the game so glitchy (i've died randomly in midair, got launched to oblivion, got kicked around chasms, you get the point) and badly optimized won't give you an excuse to put this out there and expect praise. Especially when you're charging money for it.

Please don't waste your money on this. 

"What this is, an object". - 10/10

review: KRUM is a linera action RPG. I've played about seven hours so far, and have enjoyed most of them. It doesn't offer massive RPG depth, but has cool environments that swap out just about the time when you start wanting some new scenery. It offers some combination-based combat, but I don't find myself really using it, and the controls are a little wonky and would benefit from less vertical clamping, which feels very limited at times. I would also much rather see a standard shift key run option than the current double tap [W] key. Overall, it's a pretty simple hack and slash wih tons of cool artwork, that kept me entertained for hours. It should also be noted that it's a wildly impressive showing of what a single developer can do with the Blender Game Engine.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095641088', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 72, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1449590970}
review:
I should start out by saying that I am indeed somewhat biased. I've been following this game since I was in community college several years ago. I found the game because it was a WIP being created in the Blender Game Engine - something I was learning to use at the time. The developer's accomplishments even then absolutely astounded me, and I became dedicated to following his every update.

Reading some of the negative reviews, I feel like people are expecting this game to be something that it isn't. This game was never going to have the quality of a game created by a team of vastly experienced developers. This was created by one man using his own knowledge and experience to work with a rather complex and somewhat limited open source engine to create a game.

In my opinion, this game will best be enjoyed by those that are interested in using open source tools like Blender to create a video game. It shows what's possible - what you can do. There aren't a lot of projects out there like it, and those projects that do exist are rarely completed by their developers (one game, Elpis, is another that I followed around the same time that I started following Krum. It looked great at the time, but development eventually died off). Seeing the developer of Krum never give up despite the challenges he faced in development was encouraging and inspiring.

Seeing Krum appear in the Steam Library at last - and receiving the email with my CD-Key - was like a dream come true. Years and years of watching development, stalking a YouTube channel, and hoping that I wouldn't see the update stating that he'd cancelled the project had finally paid off. I downloaded the game and started playing, and I've not been disappointed. The game is excellently created considering it was completed by one man using an open source game engine. Not only that, but the game is still being developed and updated!

So, in conclusion:
If you set your expectations in the right place, you won't be disappointed by this game. Expect this game to be what it is: a personal project created by one developer with limited experience, using all of his own assets and skills to create something with an open source game engine. Don't expect a project that will be on-par with the Game of the Year created by a large team of developers. This game is excellent for what it is, and I'm proud to have followed it all these years.

[b]KRUM - Edge Of Darkness[/b] in an Hack'n'slash RPG developed and published by HA Studio ltd., a 1-man studio.

[h1]STORY[/h1]
The game's story is your run-of-the-mill fantasy story, only without anything interesting: an army of orcs, undead and other creatures destroys everything in their path, and you play as a farmer hellbent on getting revenge for the murder of his father, family and uncle. 

[h1]GRAPHICS[/h1]
The game does look pretty good for a 1-man job. However, there are a lot of bugs and glitches that I found while playing the game: ragdolls getting stuck in the floor or ceiling, missing ground in which you fall to your death, no skybox at the bottom of pits... Also, most of the enemies that you face all look and fight the same, adding to the overall biggest flaw of the game: its repetitiveness.

[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]
The game tries to be like one of those old-school action games that I grew up with (Rune, Gothic and Drakan being a few examples), and at the beginning I was having a blast. But after 30 minutes, and having killed the 8th enemy in the game, I understood what I got into. The game suffers from repetitiveness: while you do have combos for your weapons, most of the time you will just keep mashing the attack button to kill your enemies. You also have long-ranged weapons, but they are really useless and deal much less damage than axes or swords.
Every enemy drops some items and its weapon, giving you the possibility to change your weapons (that keep degrading). Unfortunately, they all feel the same, making the use of one over the other pointless. Exploring the environments also feels lifeless, and choosing to go straight to your objective rather than engaging in fights feels more satisfying than it should be.

[h1]CHALLENGE[/h1]
The only challenge lies in the combat. You will encounter two types of AI: one first parries, then attacks, then parries, then attacks... and the other just keeps attacking till it runs out of stamina. Both of those can be easily defeated if you understand who you are fighting. Otherwise, once you get hit by the latter AI, you are doomed to die since just a couple of hits will kill you, especially in the beginning of the game. Most of the time I found myself more frustrated than challenged, and that's not all that fun.

[h1]SOUND[/h1]
The voice acting is just as cheesy as I wanted it to be. However, the voice of our hero often feels computer-generated, often making certain situations very funny.
The soundtrack is fine, with some good tracks here and there. Often enough, the "no-enemy-around" music kept playing while the "fight" music activated while heading into battle, forcing me to completely remove the music from the game, to hear the competent but often cheap sound effects. 

[h1]REPLAYABILITY[/h1]
As far as I know, there is almost no replayability at all: no Steam or in-game achievements, difficulty settings, secrets or new game modes don't make me want to come back to this game.

Overall, I do appreciate that this game was made by only one person. But still, the repetitive combat, game-breaking glitches and frustration make this feel more like a chore than an epic fantasy. If you are really interested, pick it up on sale.

Replayability: 4

review: When I first wrote my Review for this game I was a tad bit biased and I hadn't finished the game. The old Review was for the amount I had played, and I still hold too that although now that I've beaten it I cannot give it my orignal 8/10. Its after you enter the castle things start getting "Sloppy"  the game feels very unpolished the farther you go. Gltiches where all over the place, missing textures and some other things. It picks up a bit towards the middle, but this doesnt save the game ultimatly with the end feeling very rushed and unfinished.  "Krum" does some things right, I did enjoy the combat while simple it was fun too hack your way through enemies one at a time, although this did get a bit old as the game went on. The level design was nice in some areas as well. Over all I cannot recommend this game, I really wish I could but due too the bads outwaying the goods over all, My new verdict is 4/10.
